TEXT:
Chief Complaint: STEMI/VFIB ARREST.
   24 Hour Events:
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: 51 yo man no known medical history was
   noticed to be driving erratically earlier this morning in NH and
   ultimately suffered an unrestrained MVA crashing his car into a tree.
   Did not appear to EMS to be traumatic arrest. Found apneic and
   pulseless in VF, with downtime of minutes before CPR initiated with
   EMS. Shocked 3x, epinephrine x2,atropine x1, lidocaine 2g IV then taken
   to [**Hospital3 **] Center in NH, then to [**University/College 2158**]. On arrival to the
   [**Hospital1 5**] ED he had a GCS of 7, unconscious. Initial CE were CK: 1694
   Trop-T: 4.11 and have EKG changes consistent with STEMI. He was loaded
   with [**Last Name (LF) 12105**],[**First Name3 (LF) **], integrillin, and started on heparin drip.  Within 3
   hours of his arrest he hit the cath lab and was found to have total
   occlusion of the LAD proximally with BMS placed to the ostium of the
   LAD. There was also 30% distal RCA lesion, minimal Lcx disease. He
   underwent LHC with L ventriculograpy and coronary angiography which
   noted proximal TO of LAD. A BMS was placed.
   On leaving the cath lab he was found to be hypertensive and was started
   on nitro gtt, and NGT was placed, and transferred to the CCU.
   On arrival to the CCU he was hemodynamically stable. A repeat EKG at
   that time showed improvement in his ST elevation post
   revascularization. He was weaned off nitro GTT, continued on [**First Name3 (LF) 12105**] and
   heparin GTT.
   .
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
   psoriasis
   cholecystectomy
   .
   MEDICATIONS:
   unknown
   .
   ALLERGIES:
   unknown
   .
   SOCIAL HISTORY: works as an accountant, lives in [**Location **]. Occassional EtOH.
   Quit smoking several years ago.
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY: father died of massive MI at age 47. Mother with
   ?mitral valve prolapse died at age 79 (about three months ago).
   Allergies:
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Amiodarone - 1 mg/min
   Fentanyl - 75 mcg/hour

   PO4:3.9 mg/dL

   An initial gas showed an O2 of 81 and he was placed on PEEP 12, F102
   100% with improvement in his BP to the 90s.
   Iniital labs were WBC: 23.6 , K6.5, lactate 5.1 with anion gap 17,
   dirty UA, Utox positive for opiates/amphetamines.
   .
   EKG at 0SH: 10:38: HR in 120s, LAD,LAFB depressions related to IVCD,
   SVT, sinus with ST elevation I,aVL, q waves ST elevation V2 to V5.
   over the EKGs the QRS seems to widen but that may just be because of
   the ST elevations. Overall ST elevations become more prominent as do
   the q waves. Following reperfusion, ST elevations less prominent, QRS
   narrowed, axis normalized, bbb gone.
   .
   Imaging:
   CXR: ETT tube terminates 4.3 cm above
   NGT tip in stomach.
   Thyroid appears nodular
   signif dependent edema portion of lower lobe concerning for acute

   moderate diverticulosis, none acute.
   .

    1. No acute cervical fracture or malalignment. Moderate multilevel
   degenerative disease with osteophytes may increase risk of spinal cord
   injury.
   2. Aspiration in the bilateral lung apices
   Assessment and Plan
 CARDIAC ARREST
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 51 y/o male with hx of cholecystecomy/psoriasis
   who suffered STEMI in field with VF arrest found to have TO LAD, s/p
   reperfusion with BMS to LAD.
   .
   # STEMI s/p VF arrest.
   - s/p cath with BMS to LAD
   - on [**Year (4 digits) 119**],heparin IV, atorvastatin, integrillin, Plavix (consider
   increasing Plavix to 75 [**Hospital1 **])
   - cooling protocol x24 hours
   - sedation with Fentanyl/versed
   holding metoprolol/ace given borderline Hypotension
   - EEG for 48 hours per protocol (discussed with neuro and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 92**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **])
   - keep pCO2 between 35-40
   -trend CE.
   .
   Pump: s/p TO LAD >3 hours, with infarcted myocardium.
   Poor forward flow as indicated by renal failure: FENA 0.2
   IVF for preload
   check echo s/p warming.
   .
   Rythm: V fib arrested in field.
   Currently in sinus
   continue amniodorone
   continue telemetry
   q4-6 labs with repletions during cooling.
   Judicious repletions during warming as electrolytes tend to go
   extracellular with warming.
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: Tox screen negative for ethanol.
   Lactic acid elevated. No known hx DM but hyperglycemic
   -check UA for ketones
   -IVF to close anion gap
   -q 4-6 labs
   .
   #s/p trauma
   CT spine/torso negative except for aspiration.
   NGT draining cool aide colored secretion- IV PPI.
   neck brace in place.
   appreciate surgery recs
   .
   #Leukocytosis: ? stress response. aspiration ? Positive UA
   -F/u urine cx.
   .
   Bowel reg
   FEN: NPO
   Will need tube feeds if NPO >48 hours
   GFS/SS
   .
   Status: Full Code
   Dispo: CCU for now

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI/VFIB arrest after a motor vehicle accident. He was found apneic and pulseless in VF and was resuscitated with CPR and defibrillation. He was taken to the hospital and underwent emergency coronary angioplasty with stenting of the LAD, which showed a total occlusion of the LAD proximally. He also had a 30% distal RCA lesion and minimal LCx disease.

The patient's initial presentation was comatose with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 7, and he was intubated and mechanically ventilated. He was also noted to have hypertension, which was treated with nitroglycerin.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin and CK-MB levels, consistent with myocardial infarction. His WBC count is elevated, and his differential shows a predominance of neutrophils, which may be indicative of a stress response. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but his lactate level is elevated, which may be related to his metabolic acidosis.

The patient's imaging studies show a hypodensity in the left hepatic lobe, which may be related to his liver function. His CT scan of the abdomen also shows no evidence of solid organ injury, but he does have moderate diverticulosis.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing cardiac monitoring, cooling protocol, sedation, and pain management. He is also being treated with heparin, atorvastatin, and integrillin for his cardiac condition. His metabolic acidosis is being managed with IVF and q4-6 labs.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VF arrest and ongoing cardiac monitoring may increase his risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and positive UA for opiates and amphetamines may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's mechanical ventilation and elevated lactate level may increase his risk of developing respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and FENA of 0.2 may increase his risk of developing renal failure.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap may increase his risk of developing metabolic acidosis.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's hypodensity in the left hepatic lobe may increase his risk of developing liver dysfunction.
7. Intestinal obstruction: The patient's NGT drainage and positive UA for opiates and amphetamines may increase his risk of developing intestinal obstruction.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk patient who requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, and metabolic status.

Chief Complaint:
   He initially lost his DP/PT in his left leg, and warming blankets were
   placed peripherally with recovery of his pulse
    overnight he received 4L IVF with  improvement of his lactate from 5.1
   to 2.7 closing of his anion gap with UOP 30-40cc/hr maintaing BPs with
   MAPs in the 80s. Around 6:30pm his maps dropped to the high 50
s, his
   UOP trailed off, amnio off, sedation decreased, fluids wide open,
   dobutamine was started peripherally and a central line was placed.
   He was shivering significantly with subsequent warming, initially got
   vecuronium boluses x 2 then started on vecuronium drip.
   His GFS ranged 300s to 400s with humalog given, and was started on an
   insulin drip this am.
   On Telemetry  he was in sinus with PVCs.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 51 y/o male with hx of cholecystecomy/psoriasis
   who suffered STEMI in field with VF arrest found to have TO LAD, s/p
   reperfusion with BMS to LAD.
   .
   Hypotension:
   s/p arrest, no echo as of yet, pump function is unclear.
   [**Name2 (NI) **]  stent thrombosis a possibility, with valvular compromise
   -check EKG, stat ECHO
    -continue dobutamine until has central line may also consider
   dopamine, both have more ionotrope effects than vasoconstrictorry, wean
   when tolerated
   -IVF wide open
   # STEMI s/p VF arrest.
   - s/p cath with BMS to LAD
   - on ASA,heparin IV, atorvastatin, integrillin, Plavix (consider
   increasing Plavix to 75 [**Hospital1 **])
   - cooling protocol x24 hours
   - sedation with Fentanyl/versed
   holding metoprolol/ace given borderline Hypotension
   - EEG for 48 hours per protocol (discussed with neuro and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 92**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **])
   - keep pCO2 between 35-40
   -trend CE.
   .
   Pump: s/p TO LAD >3 hours, with infarcted myocardium.
   Poor forward flow as indicated by renal failure: FENA 0.2
   IVF for preload
   check echo s/p warming.
   .
   Rythm: V fib arrested in field.
   Currently in sinus
   continue amniodorone
   continue telemetry
   q4-6 labs with repletions during cooling.

   -IVF to close anion gap
   -q 4-6 labs
   .

   IV PPI

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field and had a VF arrest. He was found to have a total occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and underwent reperfusion with a bare metal stent (BMS) to the LAD. He has been in the ICU for several days and has been experiencing hypotension, tachycardia, and decreased urine output.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 33.7°C (92.7°F), blood pressure of 67/56 mmHg, heart rate of 69 bpm, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals sluggish and equal pupils, constricted from 6mm to 3mm in response to light, and muted reflexes. His neck is braced in place, and he is unable to assess the jugular venous pressure. His chest is clear anteriorly, and his heart sounds are distant with a regular rate and rhythm. His abdomen is soft and nontender, and his extremities are mottled and purplish with slow capillary refill.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction. His lactic acid level is elevated at 2.7 mmol/L, and his glucose level is 390 mg/dL. His white blood cell count is 26.6 K/uL, and his platelet count is 286 K/uL. His creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 25 mg/dL.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Cardiac arrest: Given the patient's history of VF arrest and the presence of a total occlusion of the LAD artery, there is a high risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Myocardial infarction: The patient has already suffered a myocardial infarction, and there is a risk of further infarction or extension of the existing infarct.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactic acid level and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. He may be at risk for respiratory failure if his oxygen requirements increase.
5. Renal failure: The patient's BUN level is 25 mg/dL, which may indicate renal failure.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactic acid level is elevated, and he has hyperglycemia. He may be at risk for metabolic acidosis if his acid-base balance is not carefully monitored.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels may be abnormal, particularly his potassium and magnesium levels, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.

In terms of treatment, the patient is receiving dobutamine and amiodarone to support his cardiac function and prevent cardiac arrhythmias. He is also receiving IV fluids to maintain his blood pressure and urine output. His glucose level is being closely monitored, and he is receiving insulin therapy to control his hyperglycemia. His electrolyte levels are being monitored, and he is receiving electrolyte replacement therapy as needed.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field and was found to have a TO LAD, which was treated with a BMS to LAD. He had a VF arrest, was resuscitated, and is currently in the ICU.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hypotension: The patient had a episode of hypotension this morning that responded to fluids. He is currently on dobutamine and IVF to maintain blood pressure.
* Cardiac Arrest: The patient had a VF arrest in the field, and his cardiac function is unclear due to the lack of an echocardiogram.
* Metabolic Acidosis: The patient has lactic acidosis, which is being treated with IVF to close the anion gap.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be due to a stress response or aspiration.
* Bowel Reg: The patient is NPO and will require tube feeds if NPO for more than 48 hours.
* Status: Full Code
* Dispo: CCU for now

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Dobutamine
* IVF
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam (Versed)
* Amiodarone
* Eptifibatide (Integrilin)
* Heparin Sodium
* Atorvastatin
* Plavix
* ASA

The patient has the following lab results:

* WBC: 26.6
* Hct: 50.3
* Plt: 286
* Cr: 1.7
* TCO2: 18
* Glucose: 390
* Lactic Acid: 2.7 mmol/L
* Ca++: 7.9 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient has the following orders:

* Cooling protocol for 24 hours
* Sedation with Fentanyl/Versed
* Holding metoprolol/ace due to borderline hypotension
* EEG for 48 hours
* Keep pCO2 between 35-40
* Trend CE
* IVF for preload
* Check echo s/p warming
* Continue amiodarone
* Continue telemetry
* Q4-6 labs with repletions during cooling
* Judicious repletions during warming
* Check UA for ketones
* IVF to close anion gap
* Q 4-6 labs
* F/u urine cx
* Tube feeds if NPO >48 hours

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrest
* Metabolic acidosis
* Leukocytosis
* Bowel obstruction
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field and was found to have a TO LAD. He was resuscitated and received a BMS to LAD. He is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 33.7°C, blood pressure of 67/56 mmHg, and heart rate of 69 bpm. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. His oxygen saturation is 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of metabolic acidosis, with a lactate level of 2.7 mmol/L and an anion gap of 1.5 mg/dL. His glucose level is elevated at 390 mg/dL. His white blood cell count is 26.6, and his platelet count is 286.

The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis. He is receiving multiple medications, including aspirin, heparin, atorvastatin, integrillin, and Plavix. He is also receiving sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.

The patient's medical complications include hypotension, cardiac arrest, metabolic acidosis, hyperglycemia, and leukocytosis. He is at risk for further complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.

The patient's plan of care includes ongoing mechanical ventilation, sedation, and vasopressor support. He will require continued monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and cardiac rhythm. He will also require close monitoring for signs of sepsis and respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect early signs of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's elevated respiratory rate and decreased tidal volume suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is necessary to detect early signs of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and his current cardiac rhythm suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring of his cardiac rhythm is necessary to detect early signs of cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels suggest that he may be at risk for renal failure. Close monitoring of his renal function is necessary to detect early signs of renal failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of cholecystectomy and his current gastrointestinal bleeding suggest that he may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status is necessary to detect early signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. Close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and cardiac rhythm is necessary to detect early signs of sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, renal failure, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest, followed by reperfusion with BMS to LAD. He was intubated and received 4L IVF with improvement in his lactate levels. His MAPs dropped to the high 50s, and he was started on dobutamine and a central line was placed. He was also given vecuronium boluses and started on a vecuronium drip. His GFS ranged from 300s to 400s with humalog given, and he was started on an insulin drip this morning. He has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 35.4°C, blood pressure of 67/56 mmHg, heart rate of 69 bpm, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. His SpO2 is 100%. He has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8, and his pupils are sluggish and reactive to light.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he is at risk of further hypotension due to his cardiac arrest and possible stent thrombosis.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient suffered a VF arrest in the field, and his cardiac function is unclear.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose levels are elevated, and he is at risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, and he has a negative tox screen for ethanol.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he may have a stress response or aspiration.
6. Bowel regurgitation: The patient has a nasogastric tube draining cool-aid colored secretion, and he may need tube feeds if he is NPO for more than 48 hours.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's cardiac arrest and possible stent thrombosis may lead to cardiac tamponade.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and possible aspiration may lead to sepsis.
3. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's hyperglycemia and possible lack of insulin may lead to diabetic ketoacidosis.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactate levels may lead to metabolic acidosis.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and he may be at risk of developing respiratory failure.
6. Renal failure: The patient's poor forward flow and elevated creatinine levels may lead to renal failure.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and possible hypotension may lead to neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field and was found to have a TO LAD, treated with reperfusion with a BMS to LAD. He was in VF arrest and was resuscitated. He is currently intubated and sedated with Fentanyl and Versed. His lactate level has improved from 5.1 to 2.7, and his anion gap has closed. He is being treated for hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and cardiac arrest. He has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest in the field and subsequent VF arrest may have caused damage to his heart, leading to further complications.
2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's elevated lactic acid level and metabolic acidosis may be a sign of inadequate perfusion or shock, which can lead to further complications if not addressed.
3. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may be a sign of insulin resistance or diabetes, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count may be a sign of stress response or infection, which can lead to further complications if not addressed.
5. Respiratory Complications: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory complications such as pneumonia or respiratory failure if not managed properly.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and VF arrest may have caused neurological damage, leading to further complications such as seizures or stroke.
7. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and metabolic acidosis may be a sign of sepsis, which can lead to further complications if not addressed.
8. DVT: The patient's immobility and cardiac arrest may increase his risk of developing DVT, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Continue amiodarone and telemetry to monitor his cardiac rhythm.
2. Monitor his lactate level and metabolic acidosis, and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
3. Continue to manage his hyperglycemia and insulin resistance.
4. Monitor his white blood cell count and consider further evaluation for infection.
5. Continue to monitor his respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
6. Consider further evaluation for neurological damage and consider consultation with neurology.
7. Continue to monitor his electrolyte levels and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
8. Consider further evaluation for DVT and consider consultation with vascular surgery.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest and was found to have a TO LAD. He underwent reperfusion with a BMS to LAD and is currently in the ICU. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 34.5°C, heart rate of 107 bpm, and blood pressure of 96/62 mmHg. He is intubated and ventilated, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 172.

The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis, and is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy. He is also receiving treatment for his MI, including ASA, atorvastatin, and Plavix.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating ongoing myocardial damage. His fibrinogen level is elevated, suggesting a bleeding diathesis. His platelet count is decreased, and his lactate level is elevated, indicating ongoing tissue hypoperfusion.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Bleeding: The patient's fibrinogen level is elevated, suggesting a bleeding diathesis. This increases the risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's MI and ongoing myocardial damage increase the risk of cardiac complications, including cardiac arrest, ventricular arrhythmias, and heart failure.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient's intubation and ventilation increase the risk of respiratory complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory failure, and pneumothorax.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of VF arrest and ongoing neurological symptoms increase the risk of neurological complications, including stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and ongoing invasive procedures increase the risk of infection, including sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of cholecystectomy and ongoing anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, including bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
7. Renal complications: The patient's history of hypertension and ongoing anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of renal complications, including acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health status:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU, with a complex medical history. Over the past 24 hours, the patient has experienced significant bleeding from various lines and tubes, including the arterial line, which was removed. The patient has also had a large amount of old blood from the nasogastric tube (NGT).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 34.5°C (94.1°F), heart rate of 107 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 96/62 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a SpO2 of 99% and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute.

The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with a total bilirubin of 14.3 mg/dL and an alanine transaminase (ALT) of 108 mg/dL.

The patient's medications include IV PPI, fentanyl, dobutamine, midazolam, and amiodarone. The patient is also receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding from various lines and tubes is a significant concern, and may lead to hypovolemic shock if not properly managed.
2. Infection: The patient's elevated LFTs and fibrinogen levels suggest the possibility of an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's requirement for mechanical ventilation and high levels of oxygen support suggest a high risk of respiratory failure, which could lead to prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased morbidity.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's use of dobutamine and amiodarone suggests cardiac instability, and the patient's elevated troponin-T levels suggest potential cardiac damage.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's bleeding and elevated fibrinogen levels suggest a coagulopathy, which could lead to further bleeding and increased risk of complications.

Based on this summary and the potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Close monitoring of the patient's bleeding and coagulation status.
2. Aggressive management of the patient's infection, including administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and consideration of additional therapies such as bronchoscopy and/or percutaneous drainage.
3. Optimization of the patient's respiratory status, including adjustment of mechanical ventilation and oxygen support as needed.
4. Cardiac monitoring and management, including consideration of additional therapies such as vasopressors and/or inotropes.
5. Regular review of the patient's laboratory results and medical status to ensure timely identification and management of potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU. The patient's condition has been complicated by bleeding from various lines and the NG tube, with elevated fibrinogen levels on lab results. The patient has also experienced old blood from the NG tube and bleeding from the lines, which may indicate a bleeding disorder or coagulopathy.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 34.5°C (94.1°F), heart rate of 107 bpm, and blood pressure of 96/62 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99% on 50% FiO2, and their respiratory support is being provided through an endotracheal tube.

The patient's physical examination reveals sluggish pupils, equal and round, with reflexes that are muted. The patient's neck is braced, and their chest is clear anteriorly. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no masses palpated. The patient's extremities are mottled and purplish, with slow capillary refill and weak peripheral pulses.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with a low hematocrit. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and their creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are elevated. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing ICU care, nutrition, and glycemic control. The patient is at risk for bleeding, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and prophylactic measures are being taken to prevent these complications.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding from various lines and the NG tube may indicate a bleeding disorder or coagulopathy, which may worsen if not addressed.
2. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated fibrinogen levels and bleeding from lines may indicate a coagulopathy, which may increase the risk of bleeding and other complications.
3. Cardiac injury: The patient's elevated troponin-T level may indicate cardiac injury, which may worsen if not addressed.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support through an endotracheal tube may not be sufficient to meet their oxygen needs, and they may require further respiratory support or mechanical ventilation.
5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate sepsis, which may worsen if not addressed.
6. DVT: The patient's immobility and risk factors may increase their risk of developing DVT, which may worsen if not addressed.
7. VAP: The patient's risk factors and respiratory support may increase their risk of developing VAP, which may worsen if not addressed.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and ensure their optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI (ST-elevation myocardial infarction) in the field with VF (ventricular fibrillation) arrest, resulting in a TO (total occlusion) of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. He underwent reperfusion with a bare-metal stent (BMS) to the LAD. The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis.

The patient's current condition is critical, with hypotension, cardiac rhythm disturbances, and metabolic acidosis. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 480 mL, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac damage, as well as elevated lactate levels, indicating metabolic acidosis. His white blood cell count is elevated, possibly indicating a stress response or aspiration.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's TO LAD and VF arrest may lead to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory failure, and hypoxemia.
3. Metabolic complications: The patient's metabolic acidosis may lead to complications such as electrolyte imbalances, kidney failure, and cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's VF arrest and subsequent resuscitation may lead to neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, and cognitive impairment.
5. Infection complications: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation may lead to infection complications such as pneumonia, sepsis, and multi-organ failure.
6. Hemorrhagic complications: The patient's coagulopathy and elevated fibrinogen levels may lead to hemorrhagic complications such as bleeding from lines, NG tubes, and other sites.
7. Renal failure: The patient's hypotension and cardiac damage may lead to renal failure, which can exacerbate the patient's metabolic acidosis and electrolyte imbalances.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment, including:

1. Cardiac monitoring: The patient should be closely monitored for cardiac rhythm disturbances, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory support: The patient should receive mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Fluid management: The patient should receive aggressive fluid resuscitation to maintain adequate blood pressure and perfusion.
4. Medication management: The patient should receive medications such as dobutamine, amiodarone, and fentanyl to manage cardiac rhythm disturbances, hypotension, and pain.
5. Nutritional support: The patient should receive nutritional support, including total parenteral nutrition (TPN), to maintain adequate caloric and nutritional intake.
6. Infection prevention: The patient should receive infection prevention measures, including antibiotics and antifungals, to prevent infection complications.
7. Hemorrhagic control: The patient should receive hemorrhagic control measures, including blood transfusions and hemostatic agents, to control bleeding.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to manage his critical condition and prevent potential complications.

* Hold metoprolol and ace due to borderline hypotension
* Monitor neuro exam and consider EEG for 48 hours
* Wean pressors as tolerated
* Continue IV amiodarone and switch to PO as tolerated
* Monitor hematocrit and transfuse for Hct <30
* Trend leukocytosis
* Continue stress ulcer prophylaxis and VAP prophylaxis
* Monitor for signs of bleeding and infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI (ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction) in the field with VF (ventricular fibrillation) arrest, followed by a TO (thrombus) in the LAD (left anterior descending) artery. He underwent reperfusion with a BMS (bare metal stent) to the LAD.

The patient developed respiratory distress overnight, with a CXR (chest X-ray) showing pulmonary edema. The etiology of the pulmonary edema is unclear, but it may be related to transient hypertension or flash pulmonary edema. The patient was treated with lasix bolus and nitro gtt, and was able to be weaned off BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure).

The patient's cardiac function is severely depressed, with an EF (ejection fraction) of 20-25%. He has mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, and the left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated.

The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis. He is currently taking ASA (aspirin), atorvastatin, and Plavix, and will be started on metoprolol tartrate TID. His blood pressure is currently controlled, but he is at risk for hypotension.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may be related to his pulmonary edema, and he may require further treatment to improve his oxygenation.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's severely depressed EF and dilated ventricle may indicate cardiac failure, and he may require further treatment to improve his cardiac function.
3. Infection: The patient's pulmonary edema and respiratory distress may increase his risk of infection, and he should be monitored closely for signs of infection.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's VF arrest and subsequent cooling and rewarming may have caused neurological damage, and he should be monitored closely for signs of neurological decline.
5. Hematocrit drop: The patient's hematocrit has dropped from 50 to 40, and he may require further treatment to stabilize his hematocrit.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be related to his stress response, and he should be monitored closely for signs of infection or other complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment to manage his respiratory, cardiac, and neurological status. He should be monitored for signs of infection, and his hematocrit and leukocytosis should be closely monitored to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's health progress in the ICU:

**Respiratory Status:** The patient developed respiratory distress overnight, which was treated with Lasix, morphine, nitro, oxygen, and positioning. The patient's oxygen saturation improved with diuresis.

**Cardiac Status:** The patient had a STEMI in the field, which was treated with reperfusion with a BMS to the LAD. The patient's ejection fraction (EF) is severely depressed at 20-25%. The patient's rhythm is currently sinus, and IV amiodarone was loaded and switched to PO.

**Neurological Status:** The patient was initially disoriented and confused but is now conversant. The patient is able to move all four extremities spontaneously.

**Hematocrit Drop:** The patient's hematocrit dropped initially due to bloody fluid in the NGT, but it is now stable.

**Leukocytosis:** The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to a stress response.

**Fluid Status:** The patient is at risk of fluid overload, and fluid status needs to be closely monitored.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pulmonary Edema:** The patient's flash pulmonary edema may recur if fluid overload is not managed.
2. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's severely depressed EF and history of STEMI put them at risk for cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or sudden cardiac death.
3. **Neurological Complications:** The patient's initial disorientation and confusion may recur if their neurological status is not closely monitored.
4. **Bleeding Complications:** The patient's hematocrit drop and history of STEMI put them at risk for bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
5. **Infection Complications:** The patient's history of aspiration and insertion of lines and tubes puts them at risk for infection complications, such as pneumonia, bacteremia, or sepsis.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and fluid overload.
2. Titrate the patient's beta blocker to achieve a heart rate of 60-70 beats per minute.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust their anticoagulation therapy as needed.
4. Continue to trend the patient's hematocrit and transfuse as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust their antibiotic therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust their anticoagulation therapy as needed.
7. Consider consulting a cardiologist or intensivist for further management of the patient's cardiac status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI (ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction) with VF (ventricular fibrillation) arrest, followed by successful reperfusion with a bare-metal stent (BMS) to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 37.8°C (100°F), heart rate 100 bpm, blood pressure 116/72 mmHg, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 94%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) 12 mmHg, cardiac index 2.5 L/min, systemic vascular resistance (SVR) 1,200 dyne·s/cm⁵.
* Fluid balance: Total input 991 mL, total output 1,130 mL, with a net balance of -139 mL.
* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation stopped, oxygen delivered through a CPAP mask, and assisted ventilation with a tidal volume of 820 mL.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25%, with distant heart sounds and no murmurs appreciated.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, with decreasing oxygen saturations and increasing respiratory rate. A chest X-ray showed extensive bilateral opacities, which were treated with Lasix, morphine, nitro, oxygen, and positioning, resulting in improved oxygen saturation.

The patient has also been experiencing leukocytosis, likely due to a stress response, and has a hematocrit drop from 50 to 40 due to bloody fluid in the nasogastric tube.

The plan for the patient includes:

* Continuing ASA, atorvastatin, and Plavix.
* Holding metoprolol and ace inhibitors due to borderline hypotension.
* Performing an EEG for 48 hours per protocol.
* Following up with an echo and neuro recommendations.
* Weaning pressors as tolerated.
* Continuing IV amiodarone and switching to PO.
* Monitoring the patient's neuro exam and neck.
* Trending hematocrit and maintaining active transfusion service.
* Transfusing for a hematocrit <30.
* Continuing to monitor the patient's respiratory status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or cardiogenic shock.
* Neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
* Hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the nasogastric tube or gastrointestinal tract.
* Infections, such as sepsis or pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular complications, such as hypotension or cardiac arrest.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest and was found to have a TO LAD. He underwent reperfusion with a BMS to LAD. The patient was intubated and on invasive ventilation until today, when he was extubated. He has been experiencing respiratory distress, and his oxygen saturations have been decreasing. He has been treated with Lasix, morphine, nitroglycerin, and oxygen, and has shown improvement.

The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis. He has been prescribed ASA, atorvastatin, and Plavix, and is currently taking metoprolol and amiodarone. He has been holding his blood pressure at 116/72 mmHg.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.8°C
* Heart rate: 100 bpm
* Blood pressure: 116/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 94%
* Heart rhythm: sinus tachycardia

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.3
* Hematocrit: 41.5
* Platelet count: 230
* Creatinine: 1.5
* Troponin-T: 9.28
* Glucose: 102

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's oxygen saturations have been decreasing, and he has been experiencing respiratory distress. He may be at risk for further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of STEMI and VF arrest, and may be at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Bleeding complications: The patient has been bleeding from his NG tube, and may be at risk for further bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has been experiencing neurological symptoms, such as decreased movement and tone, and may be at risk for further neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
5. Infection: The patient has been at risk for infection, particularly pneumonia, due to his respiratory distress and prolonged hospitalization.
6. Thrombotic complications: The patient has been prescribed anticoagulation therapy, and may be at risk for thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has been experiencing gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea and vomiting, and may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest, and was found to have a TO LAD. He was s/p reperfusion with a BMS to LAD and has been in the ICU since admission. Overnight, the patient was extubated and dobutamine was weaned off. The patient's echo showed an EF of 20-25% with global hypokinesis. The patient's HR was 110 with a BP of 120s/80, and metoprolol 12.5 mg PO was given. The patient experienced decreasing oxygen saturations and increasing respiratory distress, and was treated with Lasix, morphine, nitroglycerin, oxygen, and positioning, resulting in diuresis and improvement in oxygen saturation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's EF of 20-25% with global hypokinesis suggests significant cardiac dysfunction, which may lead to further complications such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, or cardiac failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory distress and decreased oxygen saturation may lead to further respiratory complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's VF arrest and subsequent cooling/rewarming may have caused neurological damage, which could lead to complications such as seizures, brain edema, or cerebral vasospasm.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's bloody fluid in the NGT and hematocrit drop may indicate bleeding complications, which could worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Infection complications: The patient's ICU stay and presence of lines and drains may increase the risk of infection, such as central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's bloody fluid in the NGT and potential stress ulcer may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
7. Renal complications: The patient's decreased urine output and potential bleeding may lead to acute kidney injury (AKI) or chronic kidney disease (CKD).

These potential complications will require close monitoring and prompt management to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU. The patient's condition has been unstable, with multiple episodes of respiratory distress, hypoxia, and cardiac arrest.

The patient was previously intubated and required invasive ventilation, but was successfully extubated overnight. However, they experienced decreasing oxygen saturations and increasing respiratory distress, requiring treatment with Lasix, morphine, nitroglycerin, and oxygen.

The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25% and a heart rate of 110 bpm with a blood pressure of 120s/80 mmHg. They were given metoprolol 12.5 mg PO x 1, which may indicate a concern for tachycardia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and troponin-T level, indicating potential cardiac and inflammatory stress.

The patient's fluid balance is concerning, with a total fluid input of 991 mL and a total fluid output of 1,130 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 139 mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturations decreased overnight, and they required treatment with Lasix and oxygen. This suggests a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's EF is low, and they experienced cardiac arrest. This increases the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac rupture.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, lactate level, and troponin-T level suggest potential sepsis.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's negative fluid balance and high fluid input/output ratio suggest a high risk of fluid overload.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is elevated, which may increase the risk of complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.

Given the patient's unstable condition, close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and address potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall male who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and a history of cardiac arrest. He has been treated with vanc/cefepime/flagyl for possible aspiration pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has severe infiltrative pulmonary abnormality on CXR, which may represent pulmonary edema, but a component of hemorrhage or aspiration pneumonia is impossible to assess. He is being treated with bipap and is on oxygen therapy.
* Cardiac: The patient had a STEMI with VF arrest and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting. He has been treated with aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, and heparin.
* Neurological: The patient is poorly oriented and has altered mental status. He is being managed with ativan and morphine for agitation.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 14.3, hemoglobin is 13.8 g/dL, and platelet count is 197 K/uL. His troponin-T level is 7.78 ng/mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows severe infiltrative pulmonary abnormality, which may represent pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further respiratory support.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and poor orientation may be related to his cardiac arrest or other underlying medical conditions.
5. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate infection.
6. Bleeding: The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy, which may increase his risk of bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued treatment with vanc/cefepime/flagyl for possible aspiration pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Repeat CXR to assess for progression of pulmonary infiltrates
* Monitor I/O off lasix to assess for fluid overload
* Repeat ABG to assess for respiratory acidosis
* Monitor O2 sats to assess for hypoxia
* Continue bipap therapy
* Await blood culture results
* Consider adding ACE inhibitor for cardiac protection
* Continue heparin and coumadin therapy
* Check coags to assess for bleeding risk
* Hold betablockade and continue telemetry to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias
* Continue ativan and morphine therapy for agitation
* Follow-up with neuro team to assess for neurological recovery and potential need for MRI brain with DWI or ADC
* Consider Haldol therapy for agitation
* Continue PPI therapy for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

   - Give 2 weeks to determine prognosis of anterograde  amnesia.
   .consider Haldol if needed, check QTC.
   .

   to NGT draining old blood yesterday. Neuro recs neck collar or neck MRI
   to ensure neck stability.
   - Continue PPI

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of cardiac arrest, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and altered mental status. He has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has severe infiltrative pulmonary abnormality on CXR, which may represent pulmonary edema, aspiration pneumonia, or pulm hemorrhage. He is being treated with vanc/cefepime/flagyl.
* Cardiac: The patient had a STEMI with VF arrest, and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. He has a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20-25% with global hypokinesis.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, is poorly oriented, and is being managed with ativan and morphine. He is at risk for biparietal hypoperfusion and agitation.
* Other: The patient has a history of trauma, with a negative CT scan of the spine and torso except for aspiration. He has a nasogastric tube (NGT) draining old blood and is being treated with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's reduced LVEF and global hypokinesis may lead to cardiac failure or arrhythmias.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and risk of biparietal hypoperfusion may worsen, leading to further neurological decline.
* Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of NGT may increase the risk of infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's reduced platelet count and presence of NGT may increase the risk of bleeding.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care should be considered:

* Continue treatment for ARDS with vanc/cefepime/flagyl.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
* Continue cardiac medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, and metoprolol, and consider adding an ACE inhibitor.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider imaging studies, such as MRI, to rule out cerebral edema or other neurological complications.
* Continue to manage the patient's pain and agitation with morphine and ativan, as needed.
* Consider Haldol for agitation if necessary, and check QTC.
* Continue PPIs for prophylaxis against stress ulceration.
* Monitor the patient's glucose levels closely and adjust insulin sliding scale as needed.
* Consider adding an anticoagulant, such as warfarin, to prevent thrombotic complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of cardiac arrest, STEMI, and VF arrest. He has been diagnosed with altered mental status, hyperglycemia, and cardiac arrest. He is currently being treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and cardiac medications. He has also been diagnosed with pulmonary edema and possible aspiration pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration. Pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or ventilator-associated pneumonia may worsen his respiratory status.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, STEMI, and VF arrest, and is at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac tamponade.
3. Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status and is at risk for further neurological deterioration, including seizures, stroke, or brain edema.
4. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk for infectious complications, including sepsis, septic shock, or endocarditis, particularly with the presence of a central line and the use of antibiotics.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of aspiration and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
6. Renal complications: The patient is at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to his cardiac condition, hypotension, and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
7. Hematological complications: The patient is at risk for bleeding complications, particularly with the use of anticoagulation therapy and cardiac medications.
8. Metabolic complications: The patient is at risk for hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or electrolyte imbalances due to his cardiac condition, medications, and nutritional status.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-inch tall male, weighing 103.3 kg, who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, hyperglycemia, and cardiac arrest. He had a STEMI with VF arrest and was found to have a total occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. He was treated with a balloon angioplasty and stenting (BMS) and was started on aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, and lisinopril.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/67 mmHg. He is on BiPAP and is receiving oxygen therapy. His respiratory support includes a non-rebreather mask and a CPAP/PSV ventilator mode.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating myocardial infarction. His white blood cell count is elevated, and his hemoglobin level is decreased. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, and his creatinine level is normal.

The patient's physical examination reveals mild agitation, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13. His peripheral perfusion is normal, and his breath sounds are absent due to the presence of a chest tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory support is being managed with BiPAP, but he may require further interventions, such as intubation or mechanical ventilation, if his respiratory status deteriorates.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and STEMI may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, or cardiac tamponade.
3. Infection: The patient's positive sputum culture and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of pneumonia or other infections.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and poor orientation may indicate neurological complications, such as stroke, encephalitis, or seizures.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of aspiration and the presence of a chest tube may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or bleeding.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased hemoglobin level may indicate renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and STEMI may lead to hemorrhagic complications, such as bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract or other sites.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory support. Further interventions, such as antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and cardiac medications, may be necessary to manage the patient's condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-inch tall, 103.3 kg male with a history of cardiac arrest, pneumonia, and anterograde amnesia. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress, altered mental status, and hyperglycemia. He has been managed with antibiotics, BiPAP, and sedatives. His lab results show elevated LFT, troponin-T, and lactate levels. His cardiac function is compromised, with an LVEF of 20-25%. He is on a range of medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and heparin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to pneumonia, aspiration, or VAP. He requires close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics, BiPAP, and other respiratory support measures.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's anterograde amnesia and altered mental status may be indicative of a neurological disorder. He requires close monitoring and treatment with anticonvulsants, sedatives, and other medications as needed.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated LFT, troponin-T, and lactate levels may indicate sepsis. He requires close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics, fluids, and other medications as needed.
5. Bloodstream infection: The patient's positive blood culture and elevated white blood cell count may indicate a bloodstream infection. He requires close monitoring and treatment with antibiotics, and other medications as needed.
6. Thromboembolic events: The patient's elevated D-dimer levels and history of cardiac arrest may indicate a risk of thromboembolic events. He requires close monitoring and treatment with anticoagulants and other medications as needed.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of aspiration and gastrointestinal bleeding may indicate a risk of gastrointestinal complications such as perforation, obstruction, or hemorrhage. He requires close monitoring and treatment with antacids, H2 blockers, and other medications as needed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and treatment with a range of medications and therapies to manage his respiratory, cardiac, neurological, and gastrointestinal complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest and was found to have a total occlusion of the LAD. He was resuscitated and received a BMS to the LAD. He has been in the ICU for several days and has been experiencing respiratory distress, likely due to pneumonia or VAP. He has also been experiencing episodes of agitation, which has been treated with haldol. His LFTs have been elevated, likely due to the recent MI, and he has been started on statin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He has also been started on heparin and coumadin for thromboembolism prevention.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia or VAP: The patient's respiratory distress may be due to pneumonia or VAP, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's recent MI and VF arrest may have caused cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's anterograde amnesia may be a sign of a neurological complication, such as a stroke or traumatic brain injury.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated LFTs may be a sign of an infection, such as sepsis, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly and effectively.
5. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants, such as heparin and coumadin, may increase his risk of bleeding, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly and effectively.
6. Kidney Injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level may indicate kidney injury, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly and effectively.
7. Liver Injury: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver injury, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly and effectively.

Assessment:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. He is at risk for a variety of medical complications, including pneumonia or VAP, cardiac complications, neurological complications, infection, bleeding, kidney injury, and liver injury. He requires ongoing treatment and monitoring to prevent and manage these complications.

* Cardiovascular: STEMI with VF arrest, with a total occlusion of the LAD on cath, treated with BMS to the LAD, and currently stable without pressors or dilators.
* Neurological: Mental status seems to be improving, with the patient more oriented this morning, and neuro recommends giving 2 weeks to determine prognosis of anterograde amnesia.
* Gastrointestinal: Elevated LFTs, with AST, ALT, and LDH likely related to recent MI, and etiology of elevated T.Bili not entirely clear.
* Hematological: Elevated WBC count, with 15.8, 15.4, and 13.6 on previous lab results.
* Renal: Normal creatinine and BUN levels.
* Electrolytes: Normal sodium, potassium, and phosphorus levels.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia, aspiration, or VAP, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Cardiac complications, such as recurrent VF arrest, cardiogenic shock, or heart failure.
* Neurological complications, such as worsening anterograde amnesia, seizure, or stroke.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as worsening liver function, pancreatitis, or gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Hematological complications, such as bleeding, coagulopathy, or disseminated intravascular coagulation.
* Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, or electrolyte imbalance.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia, aspiration, or VAP.
* Cardiovascular medications, such as aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, and lisinopril.
* Neurological medications, such as haldol for agitation.
* Gastrointestinal medications, such as metronidazole for elevated LFTs.
* Hematological medications, such as heparin and coumadin for thromboembolism prevention.
* Renal medications, such as furosemide for fluid management.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Respiratory support, including non-rebreather mask and CPAP/PSV.
* Cardiovascular monitoring, including telemetry and echocardiogram.
* Neurological monitoring, including orientation and mental status assessment.
* Gastrointestinal monitoring, including liver function tests and electrolyte levels.
* Hematological monitoring, including complete blood count and coagulation studies.
* Renal monitoring, including creatinine and BUN levels.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is currently in the CCU for further management and monitoring.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a STEMI with VF arrest. He has been experiencing respiratory distress, likely due to pneumonia or VAP, and has been treated with antibiotics. He has also been experiencing episodes of agitation and has been given haldol to manage his symptoms.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated LFTs, likely related to his recent MI. His cardiac function is compromised, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20-25%. He has been started on metoprolol and heparin to manage his cardiac status.

The patient's neuro status is improving, but he remains disoriented to time and has anterograde amnesia. He has been recommended for an MRI brain with DWI or ADC when he is stable.

The patient's medical history is significant for a recent MI, and he has been prescribed aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He has also been started on heparin and coumadin for thromboembolism prevention.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's compromised cardiac function may lead to further complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's anterograde amnesia may worsen, and he may experience further neurological decline.
4. Infection: The patient's pneumonia or VAP may progress, leading to sepsis or organ failure.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulants may increase his risk of bleeding complications.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and to adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest, resulting in a total occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. He underwent reperfusion with a bare-metal stent (BMS) to the LAD. He has been admitted to the ICU for management of respiratory distress, hypotension, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs).

The patient's respiratory status has improved with the use of non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) and high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC). He continues to require oxygen therapy to maintain an SpO2 of 95%.

His cardiac status is stable, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20-25% with global hypokinesis. He is being treated with metoprolol, heparin, and coumadin to prevent thromboembolism and manage his LV hypokinesis.

The patient's liver function tests are trending down, but he will require further evaluation if his LFT abnormalities fail to resolve completely.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if he develops pneumonia or aspiration, or if his congestive heart failure worsens.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, sepsis, or medication side effects. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
3. Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs may continue to be elevated, which could indicate ongoing liver damage or inflammation.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's LV hypokinesis may lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or thromboembolism.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's mental status may continue to be affected by his underlying medical condition, and he may develop residual deficits.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly pneumonia, due to his respiratory distress and immunocompromised state.
7. Bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulant medications increases his risk of bleeding, particularly if his platelet count is low.
8. Thromboembolism: The patient is at risk of developing thromboembolism due to his LV hypokinesis and use of anticoagulant medications.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's respiratory, cardiac, and liver function, as well as his neurological and hematological status. Further evaluation and management of his underlying medical conditions are necessary to prevent complications and promote his recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest, was found to have total occlusion of the LAD, and underwent reperfusion with BMS to the LAD. He was intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient has a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis. He has been experiencing respiratory distress, likely due to pneumonia, aspiration, or VAP, and has a positive sputum culture. He has also been experiencing episodes of agitation and anxiety. The patient's labs show elevated LFTs, likely related to the recent MI, and a low LVEF on echo. He is currently on aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and heparin, and is being treated for his respiratory distress and agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress and positive sputum culture suggest that he may have pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory compromise and potential sepsis.
2. Aspiration: The patient's respiratory distress and positive sputum culture also suggest that he may have aspirated, which could lead to further respiratory compromise and potential sepsis.
3. VAP: The patient's respiratory distress and positive sputum culture also suggest that he may have VAP, which could lead to further respiratory compromise and potential sepsis.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's STEMI and low LVEF on echo suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's anterograde amnesia and confusion suggest that he may be at risk for neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, and cognitive decline.
6. Sepsis: The patient's positive sputum culture and elevated LFTs suggest that he may be at risk for sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ failure and potential death.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and positive sputum culture suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory failure, which could lead to the need for mechanical ventilation and potential death.
8. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of VF arrest and STEMI suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac arrest, which could lead to death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pneumonia, aspiration, and VAP with antibiotics and other appropriate therapies.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent neurological complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust his insulin sliding scale as necessary to prevent hypoglycemia.
6. Consider ordering a MRI brain with DWI or ADC to evaluate the patient's neurological status.
7. Consider ordering a stress test to evaluate the patient's cardiac status.
8. Consider ordering a complete blood count to evaluate the patient's hematological status.

Summary:

The patient is a 51-year-old male who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest, resulting in a total occlusion of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. He underwent reperfusion with a bare metal stent (BMS) to the LAD. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, likely due to pneumonia or aspiration, and possible contribution from congestive heart failure. He has also been diagnosed with LLL pneumonia and sputum growing MSSA and gram negatives. The patient's labs show elevated LFTs, which are trending down, likely related to the recent MI. He has also been diagnosed with hypotension, which is being managed by holding diuresis and holding parameters on BP meds.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and gram-negative sepsis may progress, leading to sepsis, which could require aggressive management with antibiotics and vasopressors.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's STEMI and BMS placement may lead to cardiac complications such as ventricular arrhythmias, heart block, or cardiogenic shock.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient's recent VF arrest and cooling protocol may lead to neurological complications such as cognitive impairment, seizures, or stroke.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver dysfunction, which could lead to gastrointestinal complications such as ascites, encephalopathy, or bleeding.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's hypotension and potential sepsis may lead to renal complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and sepsis may lead to infection, which could require aggressive management with antibiotics and surgical intervention.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis, and consider adding additional antibiotics if the patient's condition worsens.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medications as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and consider imaging studies such as MRI to evaluate for potential neurological complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider further evaluation for liver dysfunction.
6. Monitor the patient's renal status and consider further evaluation for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Consider further evaluation for infection, such as imaging studies or surgical intervention, if the patient's condition worsens.

Summary:

The patient, a 51-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with a history of cholecystectomy and psoriasis, who suffered a STEMI in the field with VF arrest. He was found to have total occlusion of the LAD and underwent reperfusion with a BMS to the LAD. The patient is currently in sinus rhythm and has been started on aspirin, clopidogrel, statin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. He is also receiving coumadin for LV hypokinesis.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, likely due to pneumonia and possible contribution from congestive heart failure. His CXR is consistent with LLL pneumonia, and sputum is growing MSSA as well as gram negatives. He has been started on cefepime and ipratropium nebs, and his I/O is being monitored.

The patient has also been experiencing hypotension, likely related to his antihypertensive regimen. His LFTs are elevated, trending down, and are likely related to his recent MI. He is being monitored for any signs of sepsis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to pneumonia, which can lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.
2. Congestive heart failure: The patient's LV hypokinesis and elevated LFTs suggest that he may be at risk for congestive heart failure, which can lead to further complications such as cardiogenic shock and death.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated LFTs and possible sepsis can lead to further complications such as multi-organ failure and death.
4. LV hypokinesis: The patient's LV hypokinesis can lead to further complications such as cardiogenic shock, heart failure, and death.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to further complications such as shock, organ failure, and death.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's recent MI and LV hypokinesis may lead to neurological complications such as stroke, cognitive impairment, and death.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulants and antiplatelet agents may increase his risk of bleeding complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial bleeding, and death.
